sections.title: What are T-Bills?
sections.content: T-Bills are short-term debt instruments issued by the government to raise funds. They typically mature in less than one year.

sections.title: How They Work
sections.content: Investors buy T-Bills at a discount and receive the full face value at maturity. The difference represents the earned interest.

title: Bonds
subtitle: Long-term government or corporate debt instruments

sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Bonds are long-term investments that pay periodic interest and return the principal at maturity.

sections.title: Risk and Return
sections.content: Bonds generally offer lower risk compared to stocks but can vary depending on the issuer's credit rating.

sections.title: What are Stocks?
sections.content: Stocks, or equities, represent partial ownership in a public company. Investors buy them for potential capital appreciation (the stock price rising) and for income through dividend payments.

sections.title: Types and Risks
sections.content: There are two main types: Common stock (with voting rights) and Preferred stock (with priority on dividends). Stocks offer the greatest potential for long-term growth but also carry a higher risk due to potential dramatic price fluctuations.

sections.title: What is a Mutual Fund?
sections.content: A Mutual Fund is an investment vehicle that pools money from many investors to purchase a diversified portfolio of securities like stocks, bonds, and money market instruments.

sections.title: Key Benefits
sections.content: The funds are managed by a professional fund manager who makes investment decisions. The primary benefit is diversification, which helps reduce the risk typically associated with investing in a single stock or security.
